title: 114_hr3697
content: The Act may be cited as the "Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that funds administered by the Department of Housing and Urban Development provide significant economic opportunities for communities. Low- and very low-income persons often face barriers to access training, employment, and contracting opportunities due to the expenditure of Federal funds in their communities. The Department of Housing and Urban Development funds provide economic opportunities for communities by offering training, employment, and contracting opportunities for low- and very low-income individuals and local businesses. Past federal efforts in this area have not been fully effective and should be intensified. Funding from other federal agencies can also create significant employment and contracting opportunities. The Department of Housing and Urban Development funds create significant employment and contracting opportunities for communities where the funds are expended. SEC. 3. REPORTING; SANCTIONS FOR NONCOMPLIANCE. Section 3 of the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 is amended to include new reporting requirements for recipients of assistance, ensuring compliance with employment and contracting regulations. Recipients must report annually to the Secretary on their adherence to these requirements and the performance of their contractors and subcontractors. The Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 is amended to include new reporting requirements for recipients of assistance. Recipients must report actions taken to meet employment and contracting requirements, including future plans to address deficiencies. Additionally, subrecipients must submit monthly reports to recipients. The Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 now includes new reporting requirements for recipients of assistance. Recipients must submit monthly reports containing necessary information to ensure compliance. These reports must be made publicly available within 15 business days. Additionally, the Secretary is required to submit annual reports to Congress. The Secretary must annually report to Congress on the total federal funds subject to the Act, outcomes produced, and compliance assessments by recipients. Each annual report to Congress must include specific recommendations to reduce noncompliance, sanctions imposed, and a review of the program's effectiveness in providing jobs for low-income individuals, meeting training needs, enabling steady employment, and offering contracting opportunities for qualifying businesses. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within two years of the enactment of the Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015. The report will describe compliance, funds awarded, outcomes, and make recommendations to enhance the effectiveness of the program. The Secretary will develop procedures to assess compliance with the requirements of the Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015, review complaints of noncompliance, make determinations, and take appropriate actions to ensure compliance and prevent future noncompliance. Measures will be in place to ensure recipients and contractors comply with the requirements during the use of assistance. The Secretary will establish policies for sanctions against recipients and contractors who do not comply with the requirements of the Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015. Sanctions will be applied in a series of administrative measures, graded in severity, to ensure compliance with the assistance program. Compliance will be assessed monthly, with the Secretary evaluating each recipient and contractor at least once every 3 months. The Secretary will establish policies for sanctions against recipients and contractors who do not comply with the requirements of the Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015. Sanctions will be applied in a series of administrative measures, graded in severity, to ensure compliance with the assistance program. Sanctions shall include certain measures that are applied in all instances of a determination of a failure to comply with requirements and shall not be subject to any discretion. Such sanctions may require a recipient to enter into a compliance agreement with the Secretary. The Secretary will establish policies for sanctions against recipients and contractors who do not comply with the requirements of the Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015. Sanctions may include recapture of funds, reduction of future Department funds, and the requirement for recipients to enter into compliance agreements. The Secretary will establish policies for sanctions against noncompliance with the Section 3 Modernization and Improvement Act of 2015, including debarment, suspension, limited denial of participation, and other appropriate sanctions. SEC. 4. COVERAGE OF RENTAL ASSISTANCE DEMONSTRATION PROPERTIES. The Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions for the Rental Assistance Demonstration Program, requiring public housing agencies and property owners to provide training and employment opportunities for low- and very low-income individuals. The Rental Assistance Demonstration Program mandates public housing agencies and property owners to offer training and job opportunities to low-income individuals residing in housing developments, with priority given to residents of the assisted developments. The Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 is amended to provide assistance to participants in YouthBuild programs and other low- and very low-income individuals in the metropolitan area where the assistance is expended. Additionally, contracting under the Act excludes the rental assistance demonstration program. The Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 is amended to provide assistance to participants in YouthBuild programs and other low- and very low-income individuals in the metropolitan area where the assistance is expended. The Act excludes the rental assistance demonstration program from contracting. The Secretary requires public housing agencies and owners of multifamily properties assisted under the rental assistance demonstration program to make best efforts to award contracts for various types of work. The rental assistance demonstration program provides assistance to business concerns that offer economic opportunities for low-income individuals. Priority is given to businesses that benefit residents of the housing development receiving assistance, followed by residents of other housing developments operated by the public housing agency. The rental assistance demonstration program provides assistance to various entities, including YouthBuild programs, business concerns offering economic opportunities for low-income individuals, and businesses benefiting residents within the designated area. The program is defined as a demonstration program under the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968. The rental assistance demonstration program, defined under the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968, is conducted by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development as part of the Rental Assistance Demonstration in the Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2012.
